todos.title: 11.  Industry Analysis
todos.body: Who is in the industry, what is the standard industrial classification (SIC) code by the Census Bureau, are their industry studies, annual reports, trade associations, who are the buyers, sellers, trade magazines, business press, company directories, government sources.

todos.title: 4.      Customer Interview
todos.body: When arranging an interview to gain industry related information, make sure you have something to offer the interviewee in return for his or her time.

todos.title: 3.      Weak Bargaining Power Of Suppliers
todos.body: Suppliers have weak bargaining power when there are many suppliers that will compete for your business, obliged to contend with substitute products, industry is an important customer of the supplier group, suppliers product is not important input in buyer’s business, suppliers products are not differentiated, there are not switching costs, supplier group does not pose a threat to forward integration.)

todos.title: 7.      Maturing Industries
todos.body: Slowing growth, more competition, emphasis on cost and service, problems in adding capacity and labor, industry profits fall.

todos.title: 17.  Backward Integration
todos.body: Placing the manufacturing channels (resources to make the product or service) within the company.

todos.title: 18.  Forward Integration
todos.body: Placing the distribution/sales channels (resources to sell the product or service) within the company.  Allows greater ability to differentiate the product, better access to sales channels, better access to customer/market information, and higher price realization.

todos.title: 19.  Tapered Integration
todos.body: Placing some of the distribution or sales channels within the company and some outside of the company.  Allows for the threat of integrating more without the downsides of full vertical integration.

todos.title: 6.      Emerging Industries
todos.body: Newly formed or re-formed industry created by technological innovations, shifts in costs, emergence of new consumer needs, or other economic changes.

todos.title: 13.  Product Differentiation
todos.body: Need strong marketing, product engineering, creative flair, research, good reputation, tradition in the industry, track record, strong cooperation from channel, qualitative incentives, amenities to attract highly skilled labor

todos.title: 14.  New Focus
todos.body: Need combination of the above policies directed at the target market.

todos.title: 12.  Cost Leadership
todos.body: Need access to capital, process engineering skills, supervision of labor, ease of manufacturing, low cost distribution, tight control, control reports, structure, quantative incentives, economies of scale

todos.title: 1.      Diffusion of Proprietary Technology
todos.body: Most technology has a very short shelf life if you cannot patent it.  The more complex the technology, the more specialized and technical personnel, the greater the economies of scale, continual investment into R&D, and patent protection or gov’t regulation can prevent the diffusion of proprietary technology/knowledge.

todos.title: 20.  Quasi-Integration
todos.body: Minority equity investment, loans or loan guarantees, pre-purchase credits, options, exclusive dealing agreements, specialized logistical facilities, cooperative R&D.

todos.title: Industry Strength
todos.body: Is your industry strong (emerging 6 vs. maturing 7, fragmented 8, or declining 9)?

todos.title: Likelihood of Retaliation
todos.body: Is there a low likelihood of retaliation by dominant players?  Can you make moves for which retaliation would hurt the competitor’s broader positions or commitments?

todos.title: Competition
todos.body: Is there a low amount of competition in the industry?

todos.title: 9.      Declining Industry
todos.body: Industries that have experienced a decline in unit sales.  Causes of decline are usually technological substitution, shrinkage in customer group, shift in customer needs.

todos.title: 16.  Risks Of Vertical Integration
todos.body: Increased fixed costs and operating leverage, greater swings in earnings, reduced flexibility to change partners, higher exit barriers, greater capital investment requirement.

todos.title: 10.  Value Added Position for Weak Industries
todos.body: If your industry is not emerging, you can pursue aggressive competitive actions, purchase or acquire other business to gain market share, purchase exiting assets or customers, reduce competitors exit barriers, make commitments, share positive information, raise stakes for others, create or defend a particular niche, or harvest the resources.

todos.title: Value Added Position
todos.body: If your industry is not emerging, can you seek a value-added position? 10

todos.title: Industry Analysis
todos.body: Have you done an industry analysis? 11

todos.title: 5.      Economic Value Added
todos.body: EVA is defined as net operating profit after tax (NOPAT), less a capital charge that reflects a firm’s cost of capital.  EVA amortizing certain expenses that add long-term value to the company such as research and development and marketing.

todos.title: Fixed Costs
todos.body: Does you product have low fixed costs?

todos.title: Margins
todos.body: Does you product have high margins (product-COGS)?

todos.title: Synergies
todos.body: Does what you are doing support other businesses you own or aspects of your life?

todos.title: SWOT
todos.body: Do your strengths, and opportunities outweigh your weaknesses and threats?

todos.title: Acquisition Strategy
todos.body: Do you have superior information?  Are the number of other bidders/buyers low?  Is the condition of the economy bad?  Is the selling company sick?  Does seller have objectives/motives for sale beside maximizing the price?  Does buyer have a distinctive ability to improve operations of the seller?  Are you buying into an industry with uses for internal development?  Will acquisition help buyer’s position in its existing business?

todos.title: Piggybacked Distribution
todos.body: Do you have piggybacked distribution/existing relationships from other business ventures?

todos.title: Competitor Intelligence System
todos.body: Do you have a competitor intelligence system in place?

todos.title: Risk
todos.body: Do the returns match the risk?  Is the level of risk appropriate for your long-term goals?

todos.title: Buyers Bargaining Power
todos.body: Do the buyers have weak bargaining power? 2

todos.title: Suppliers Bargaining Power
todos.body: Do suppliers have weak bargaining power? 3

todos.title: Overcoming Barriers Strategy
todos.body: Do (or can) you provide a product or service at reduced costs (cost leadership 12), a superior product or service (differentiation 13), or a product or service for a new or niche market (new focus, disruption 14), without getting stuck in the middle?

todos.title: Diffusion of Technology
todos.body: Do (or can) you prevent the diffusion of your proprietary technology? 1

todos.title: Intellectual Property
todos.body: Do (or can) you obtain patents or copyrights?

todos.title: Economies of Scale
todos.body: Do (or can) you obtain economies of scale (if you work in large tangible products such as railroads or construction it will benefit you, if you work in smaller or less tangible products such as information technology it may make you less agile and harm you)?

todos.title: Supply Channels
todos.body: Do (or can) you lock up supply channels?

todos.title: Governmental Regulations
todos.body: Do (or can) you impose governmental regulations?

todos.title: Switching Costs
todos.body: Do (or can) you implement monetary, psychological, or effort and time switching costs?

todos.title: Proprietary Technology
todos.body: Do (or can) you have proprietary technology?

todos.title: Favorable Integration
todos.body: Do (or can) you have favorable integration? 16, 17, 18, 19, 20

todos.title: Economic Value Added
todos.body: Do (or can) you have economic value added? 5

todos.title: Domain Knowledge
todos.body: Do (or can) you have domain knowledge/learning curve advantage?

todos.title: Proprietary Marketing Advantage
todos.body: Do (or can) you have a proprietary marketing advantage?

todos.title: Favorable Locations
todos.body: Do (or can) you establish favorable locations?

todos.title: Don’t Want to or Disruption
todos.body: Do (or can) you create a product that others wouldn’t want to develop (disruption)?  * Disruption is bad if it causes to much attention and competitors flood the market.

todos.title: Scale
todos.body: Can the company grow from a local to national or global market scale?

todos.title: Relative Market Share
todos.body: Can the business gain a high relative share of its market?

todos.title: Encouraged to Exit
todos.body: Can tenuous, sick, or marginal companies in your industry be encouraged to exit?

todos.title: Demand
todos.body: By interviewing prospective customers, is there a high demand for what your are doing (i.e. does what you are doing solve a lot of peoples problems)?

todos.title: Affordability
todos.body: By interviewing prospective customers, do they have the money to pay for you to solve their problems, and will they pay? 4

todos.title: 2.      Weak Bargaining Power Of Buyers
todos.body: Buyers have weak bargaining power when there are a large number of buyers, buyers will compete, product is an insignificant portion of buyers expenses, product is unique and differentiated, switching costs are low, buyer earns high margins, buyer does not pose a credible threat of backward integration, product is important to buyer’s quality assurance, buyer has poor information.

todos.title: 15.  Benefits Of Vertical Integration
todos.body: Assures supply and demand are controlled in-house and not subject to market forces, improves bargaining power, enhances the ability to differentiate the product, elevates entry and mobility barriers.

todos.title: Locational Advantage
todos.body: Are you in the best location to fight with competitors?

todos.title: Market Signals
todos.body: Are there few market signals that indicate increased competition?

todos.title: Equal Playing Power
todos.body: Are the competitors at unequal playing power so that no one company dominates the industry?

todos.title: 8.      Fragmented Industries
todos.body: An industry in which it is tough for a firm to gain a significant market share to strongly influence the industry outcome.  Fragmented industries are created by low barriers to entry, absence of economies of scale or experience curve, high transportation costs, high inventory costs or erratic sales fluctuations, no advantages of size in dealing with buyers or suppliers, low standardization (allowing economies of scale), low exit barriers, gov’t prohibition of concentration, and newness.
